climbs.fa: Ted Schotten, Brian Cook, Willi Apflauer

content.description:
Nice climb with a burly 5.8 finish. Or step down and left for the 5.7 ramp (not recommended). 
 Pitch 1 20m - Follow the ramp near the bottom of the easy way down around a bulge to a belay ledge. 
 Pitch 2 15m - Climb up then step right onto a slab with a crack. Follow this to the overhang above. 
 Pitch 3 10m - Pull the overhang (recommended) or step down and left and follow the ramp to the top (not recommended). Also possible to exit right (also not recommended).

Takes the obvious ramp near the bottom of the easy way down gully.
Generally good gear placements.
No text - use the 'Improve This Page' link to add something useful!

climbs.name: Birthday Ridge
climbs.fa: 1956 David Fisher, Marnie Gilmour, Alan Bruce-Robertson,  Kay McCormick

content.description:
This easy climb follows a very easy ridge. Its moderate grade make it a great climb to show a non climber what the fuss is all about. 

Follows a prominent ridge in a huge corner using the picture in the online guidebook it is impossible to miss. Carry double ropes of the rappel.
Most belays are bolted. A single rack of cams and nuts plus double ropes for the rappel. Anchors are bolted.

Perhaps the best 5.5 at Bon Echo. 
 Pitch 1 20m - ascent the trace of a ramp to a wall featuring black cokey rock and continue up the wall and ramp to an obvious belay ledge. 
 Pitch 2 25m - continue up the ramp to a small sloping ledge with two bolts. 
 Pitch 3 25m - move up and left to a large ledge below an overhang. Pull the overhang and belay at two bolts.

25m north of Birthday Ridge. Belay 2m above the water level.
Generally good placements with a few pitons and bolts.

Pitch 1: Start from a low ledge, traverses low underneath a slight overhang then up the ramp moving up and left until you move left and climb up a short headwall over a mantleshelf to the first belay. About 90 ft. Pitch 2: Follow diagonally up and left and then move left underneath the overhang then up the corner over some biggish blocks to the trees. The climb starts about 25m south of
Yellow Groove and follows the next diagonal line of weakness. Generally good gear placements.

Pitch 1 - 25m - Climb up and diagonally right past a small cedar tree then follow the crack to a belay on the right side of the Birthday Ridge slab. 
 Pitch 2 - 40m - Climb the corner to where you can escape onto the slab above. Climb up until it merges with Birthday Ridge at the top.

Start as for Birthday Ridge.
Generally good gear placements.

Step off the boat and onto a small ledge.  You can build a belay right here, though it's probably easier to scramble up for 5 meters to a larger ledge with more opportunities for gear.

P1 (5.7?) From the large ledge, traverse up and right on mediocre rock (i.e., beware of loose blocks) with well spaced gear.  After 10 meters, you will find yourself at a crack below the left side of the pillar.  We climbed straight up from here for approximately 15 meters, passing a blank spot before reaching the base of the pillar, where the climbing eases up.  Build a gear anchor and belay atop the pillar.

P2 (5.9) Up and left from the belay is a finger crack that continues for 2-3 body lengths.  Have your nuts and small cams ready and fire away!  Once the crack is below you, start traversing left and slightly up, passing a piton or two and an awkwardly placed bolt.  You are aiming for a small tree in a left angling overhang.  Above the tree is a small ledge with a nest of old rusty pitons...and two brand new 1/2" bolts.  Belay here.

P3 (5.?) Climb up then left, or left then up, or diagonally past a bulge 2 meters above the belay.  Continue up varied climbing for 10 meters to gain a large ledge.  From here I'm not sure where the route is supposed to go; I'll describe how we finished.  Scramble left over a large tree, then up until just below a small overhang.  Pulling the roof and you're done.  There are a few large bolts on the ground 7 meters from the cliff edge for a belay.

Starts approximately 100 meters right of a small talus slope that marks a break in the cliff.  The route stays to the left of a large overhang.  There is a large pillar 1/3 of the way up the cliff that looks like it will topple off any day now.  The first pitch ends atop this pillar.
Standard rack to #2.  Nuts helpful

Pitch 1 35m - Move left and up onto large blocks then up to a large ledge. Traverse right and climb up the crack to a large stance. 
 Pitch 2 18m - Climb the steep wall on the left, moving up and right over a series of platforms to the obvious ramp. 
 Pitch 3 30m - Climb the easy ramp and exit via the overhang or through the shrubs.

33m right of Compulsion and 45m left of Sweet Dreams.
Generally good gear placements. Watch for loose rock.

Climb the left side of the slab to the a two bolt belay at the top. 30m 
  
 Alternatively, climb the centre of the slab past a single bolt. 5.8

Rather sparse gear, especially when climbing the direct variation.

Climb the slabby ramp via the corner to a set of bolts midway. Continue up the ramp/corner to a ledge with a large cedar and anchor bolts on the right. (Easily combined with pitch 1). Move the belay a few meters back to a steep wall (bolts). Follow a lightning bolt crack to a small roof, and either step right and around at 5.4 or continue straight up (better) at 5.6.



50m left of boris's

Standard rack

climbs.name: Front of the Pinnacle
climbs.fa: 1956 David Fisher, Marnie Gilmour, Alan Bruce-Robertson,  Kay McCormick

content.description:
The crux of this route is a spooky step from the pinnacle. This is what also makes this route so good. Exhilarating exposure on the 2nd pitch will have you laughing the whole way.

Starts on a large ramp and follows it to a pinnacle where you belay for the infamous Pinnacle pitch. Great route!! A must do.
Long slings. Small rack of cams and nuts

climbs.name: Garden Wall
climbs.fa: Bob Adams, David Atherton, Quentin Shepley

content.description:
Rarely climbed. 
 Pitch 1 35m - Climb the ramp to a small belay stance. 
 Pitch 2 27m - Follow the ramp to the top. 
 Pitch 3 35m - Continue upwards through easy terrain and shrubbery.

Second ramp from the north end of the cliff.
Generally good gear placements.

This climb is somewhat atypical for Bon Echo because there's no routefinding skills required.  Simply locate the clean cut dihedral and climb it! P1: (5.9+) Scramble up easy terrain and clip a bolt before pulling over a roof.  Another 10 meters of moderate, but slightly runout climbing puts you on a ledge below the obvious corner.  There is no pro for a ways leading up to this ledge, so make sure your gear here is solid.  Fire the obvious crux using a less than obvious sequence to gain good holds in the crack above you.  After finishing the corner, continue scrambling up nice cracks and blocks on easier terrain for 10 meters and belay at a stance atop a block. P2: (4th) Downclimb off the other side of the block and continue up and left to the top of the cliff. To find the start, walk left for 20-30 m from Knob Hill.  The route ascends a clean dihedral, which is directly below a blank face.  A bolt 5 meters off the ground marks the start.

To descend, take the "easy way down."  In other words, follow small trails climbers left from the top of the route, always following the leftmost path.  The trails are faint at times, but as you pass a bluff and start to lose elevation, the trail will become well defined.  At one point, you will scramble down a steep slab for 10 meters.  A short jaunt will bring you back to your packs. Standard rack including small nuts and a black alien (or equivalent) for the crux and a #4 camalot for the belay.

Rarely climbed. 
 Pitch 1 40m - Climb through the forest until you get to the ramp. 
 Pitch 2 40m - Climb the ramp. 
 Pitch 3 10m - Continue up the ramp to the top.

First right leaning ramp from the north end.
Generally good gear. Loose rock.

Start at a clearing in the trees, about 5m north of the narrows, beneath an obvious tree about 20m up. 
 Pitch 1 - 20m - Climb up the steep face on good holds to a tree. 
 Pitch 2 - 25m - Move left and up to the huge ledge. 
 Pitch 3 - 20m - Traverse right (crux) and continue straight up on good holds to the top.

Generally good gear placements.

Climb the open book and slab to the top.

Climb 10m up from the top of Formication and then cross right to the obvious open book.
Generally good gear.

Links the first pitch of Boris' Route with the third pitch of Moonday. Pitch 2 involves a traverse left across a grassy ledge and scramble to a belay ledge. Lichen the lichen.

Start as for Boris' Route.
Generally good gear.

A splendid route for beginners. 
 Pitch 1 - 40m - Belay from the ledge 10m up, climb near or on the outside edge, move up to a wide ledge with a good belay. 
 Pitch 2 - 28m - Go more or less straight up. 
 Pitch 3 - 40m - Climb up and move right to an obvious crack below the "pine" tree. Climb the crack and scramble to the bolted belay above.

120m north of the easy way down, at the bottom of a major ramp.
Generally good gear placements with a few pitons.

Pitch 1 20m - Climb up behind the flake then move left and ascent past a bolt and slight right to a large pine tree. 
 Pitch 2 30m - Climb the ramp to the slabs and continue up the slabs to a belay stance. 
 Pitch 3 20m - Climb the slab to the top.

10m left of the easy way down.
Generally good gear. Large cams helpful. Can combine pitches 1 and 2.

A traverse connecting Top Secret and Ottawa Route.

Begins at the first belay station of Top Secret.
Generally good gear placements.

An impressive route for beginners. 
 Get out of the boat and onto the belay ledge (crux). Climb the corner and chimney until forced onto the face by a constriction. Continue to the top.

30m north of the easy way down.
Generally good gear placements.

Pitch 1. 15m Climb directly up the wall to a comfortable belay stance or continue to the top. 
 Pitch 2. 35m Move right past a piton up good holds on a left facing corner system before moving right at the top. A variation clips a bolt on Old Faithful near the top and continues up the corner system. Frequently done in one pitch.

Start between the narrows and Vertigenous where there are very few trees between the wall and the talus slope.
Gear required.

Rarely climbed. 
 Pitch 1 35m - Climb the ramp to an small belay stance. 
 Pitch 2 20m - Step right and climb up the face above (crux). 
 Pitch 3 20m - Traverse right and climb up the left side of a pinnacle. Belay on the other side. 
 Pitch 4 25m - Take any one of many possible finish to the top.

Start as for Garden Wall.
Generally good gear placements. Lots of lichen.

The first pitch provides enjoyable climbing on small holds. The remainder of the climb is disappointing so it is common practice to rappel after the first pitch.

30m right of Sweet Dreams ramp.
Bolted rappel station at the top of first pitch.

Climb the ramp to the top. 30m

5m right of Afternoon Delight
Poor gear lower down but improves further up.

A Bon Echo classic, hands down.

p1: Scramble up the slab easily to its end, sticking towards the right side. Gear anchor. 5.3
p2: Move out left onto the face (look down, it's a fantastically exposed stance) and traverse left on good feet and somewhat crimpy hands. Use the pitons if you want, but at sometimes 50+ years old, they have a reputation for failure. Back them up. Continue to a right-facing corner and move up to a large ledge. Gear anchor (a variety of pitons are available as well). 5.6-5.7
p3: The big one. Move up the wall to climber's right on the ledge. Clip the bolt a few metres up, towards the end of the crux. The difficulty tapers off a bit, but is fairly sustained. Follow the weakness first up and slightly left to a tree, then up and right to the top. Belay on gear on a big ledge or continue to the top. 5.9+, realistically 10a/b at the crux.

Sweet Dreams starts on the first pronounced slab ramp from the North end of the cliff.
Standard rack to #2 Camalot. Full set of nuts.

Rock fall has altered this route. The new crux is protected with bolts. 
 Pitch 1 27m - Climb up right, then through the newly exposed rock and move left and up to a small ledge. 
 Pitch 2 18m - Step up and right and move further right onto the ramp. Go leftwards up the ramp. 
 Pitch 3 20m - Scramble up to the top. Try to find the "secret" break in the rock at the top to unlock the best part of the route.

Start at the top of the scree covered buttress 25m above the lack.
Generally good gear placements

Start below a large cedar tree on a ledge a third of the way up the wall.

Bolted anchor at top of first and third pitch.

Pitch 1 6m - Follow the obvious left-leaning crack over a bulge to a ledge with a cedar tree, below a leaning crack at the back of an overhang. 
 Pitch 2 25m - Climb the strenuous finger crack (crux) to a ledge with a cedar tree. Climb the overhang to the top.

Starts near the bottom of the easy way down.
Generally good gear placements.

Pitch 1 35m - climb up onto a block with a bush. Go up and left to a small tree then up and right to a sickly looking tree. Go up and right into the overhanging cleft known as the "womb". Most parties link the second pitch which scrambles up 10m to a bolted anchor.

70m north of the narrows. Take the easy way down.
Generally good gear placements.

Start at the first diagonal ramp south of Black Groove. 
 Rock fall (2011?) obliterated the first belay ledge. Climb the obvious fault, struggle behind the cedar and continue to the top. Watch for loose rock. 45m

Take the easy way down.
Bolted anchor at the top. Generally good gear placements.

Located in Bon Echo Provincial park overlooking Mazinaw lake. The wall reaches over 300ft and is made up of metamorphosed Granite. The rock can be suspect at times but it is a truly beautiful setting.
